subhead: 'Click To Pirate' (4/5). Hit later than other sectors by the scourge of piracy, the sports industry now faces a proliferation of illegal broadcasts, from Telegram to IPTV. Meanwhile, users of streaming platforms criticize what they see as inadequete legal offerings.

subhead: The US president's push to reassert control in the capital includes reshaping the country's historical narrative, through greater control over the Smithsonian and the Kennedy Center.

title: Video: Europe battles wildfires fueled by heat wave
subhead: The prolonged heatwave scorching Europe is fueling increasingly intense wildfires, driven by climate change.

title: The femicide of Tatiana Mevel exposes a society that 'does not sufficiently consider this danger'
subhead: This French mother had filed complaints twice against her former partner. For a specialist, when it comes to femicides, 'protection must come before punishment.'

title: Who's going to lie down on the couch? 'The Sopranos,' the first TV series to tackle mental health
subhead: 'Breaking The Script' (3/5). In 1999, the TV series 'The Sopranos' introduced viewers to a mafia boss suffering from depression. Through the intense exchanges between this anti-hero and his therapist, mental health became a central theme on television for the first time, where it has continued to thrive ever since.

title: 'Who shot JR?': The 'Dallas' episode that had the whole world on edge
subhead: 'Breaking The Script' (1/6). These legendary TV episodes shaped and transformed the genre. In 1980, at the end of the third season of 'Dallas,' the infamous JR Ewing was gunned down outside his office door. For eight long months, suspense over the shooter's identity kept viewers hooked. Spoiler alert!

title: The love story between an old man and his 'great oak,' the tallest of its kind in the world
subhead: At the heart of Vallespir, in the Pyrénées-Orientales, Serge Arnaudiès discovered a 300- or 400-year-old cork oak. Recognized as the tallest in the world and labeled an 'Arbre remarquable' ('Remarkable Tree'), the specimen now draws many visitors.

title: Piracy evolves to target porn actresses, left powerless by leaks
subhead: 'Click to Pirate' (3/5). Pirates siphon off content from professional erotic or pornographic performers to distribute it for free. This phenomenon sometimes also involves the circulation of non-consensual videos.
byline: By Aurélien Defer  and Florian Reynaud
